data_findings.finding: Problem: 2D irregular polygon packing - pack Christmas tree shapes (15-vertex polygons) into smallest square bounding box. Score = Σ(s²/n) for n=1 to 200. Target: 68.888293

Top kernel approach: bbox3 binary optimizer with parameters -n (iterations) and -r (radius). Multi-phase: short runs (2min) to find promising (n,r), medium runs (10min), long runs (20min). Always validate and revert on regression.

Rotation tightening (fix_direction): After placing trees, optimize rotation of entire configuration using ConvexHull + scipy.optimize.minimize_scalar on angle 0-90°. Objective: minimize max(width, height) of axis-aligned bounding box.

Academic approaches for 2D irregular packing: (1) Hybrid genetic algorithm + linear programming, (2) Jostle algorithm for local search, (3) No-Fit Polygon (NFP) for efficient collision detection, (4) Bottom-left heuristics, (5) Simulated annealing with adaptive cooling

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing optimization problems?
web_research.finding: For 2D irregular polygon packing optimization problems, several algorithms are considered effective, often tailored to specific problem characteristics. A notable approach is the hybrid method combining genetic algorithms with linear programming, which has shown promise in optimizing irregular packing by leveraging the strengths of both techniques ([MDPI](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/13/22/12474)). web_research.query: What is the No-Fit Polygon (NFP) technique for 2D polygon packing and how does it improve collision detection?
web_research.finding:
The No-Fit Polygon (NFP) technique is a geometric tool used primarily in 2D polygon packing and nesting problems to efficiently determine whether two irregular shapes overlap or can fit together without collision. It is constructed by analyzing the relative positions of two polygons and generating a shape that represents all possible placements where the polygons would touch or intersect, effectively capturing the boundary of their potential overlap regions ([Julia Bennell, 2008](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0305054806000669); [Pedro Rocha, 2019](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1903.11139); [Julia Bennell, 2005](https://eprints.soton.ac.uk/36850/1/CORMSIS-05-05.pdf)). 

The NFP improves collision detection by simplifying the complex geometric calculations involved in checking overlaps between irregular polygons.
